body: At 9:35 a.m. yesterday, the B67 bus had been stuck on Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, stretched across an intersection, for 15 minutes when a woman with a rolling suitcase knocked on the door. The driver, Al Cromartie, 54, who has been driving a city bus for 11 years and has gotten stuck on the road only once before -- during the blizzard
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 2000: THE SCENE; Aboard the B67 in Brooklyn: Red Alert in a White Tableau

body: AMY BENNETT and Morton Dubin, both lawyers, were looking for an apartment to buy on the Upper West Side. One weekend, they went to an open house on 71st Street and were totally depressed by the minuscule bedrooms and pathetic outdoor space. ''It was $750,000 for two closets and a shared garden,'' Mr. Dubin said. On impulse, they jumped on the
title: Habitats /Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn; Couple Find Fort Greene Is Just to Their Taste

body: JACQUES TORRES, the pastry chef who made his name at Le Cirque and on television, has just opened a chocolate factory and shop. It is not, as one might expect, in a prestigious precinct of high-rent Midtown, but in Brooklyn, among century-old factories in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge. ''It was what we could afford,'' Mr. Torres said. He and
title: The Chocolate Chef, Live From Brooklyn

body: The Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, a historic architectural gem in Brooklyn Heights, has shut its doors indefinitely after church officials decided last Sunday that the building was a safety hazard for its congregation. St. Ann's, an Episcopal church that housed a well-known arts center until this past summer, when the two rancorously
title: Historic Brooklyn Church Closes for Safety Reasons

body: A sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.) This selection, compiled by Paul Griffiths, represents what caught this critic's eye and excited his expectations. More holiday recommendations for this weekend are
title: Carolers and Choristers Ring In the Holiday Season

body: A Queens contractor that illegally underpaid workers on renovations of New York City buildings will pay $1.9 million to more than 100 employees. Alan G. Hevesi, the city's comptroller, said an agreement by Classic Electric Inc., of Astoria to pay the wages due plus interest represented the largest amount of back pay ever from a contractor that
title: Underpaid Construction Workers Get $1.9 Million

body: Like any other show, yesterday's performance of ''Sunday Brunch 4'' began shortly after the doors closed and the audience got settled. Except, in this case, the doors were shiny, metal and mobile, and the audience just happened to be along for the ride. That's because ''Sunday Brunch 4'' was performed, as were two earlier versions, on a southbound
title: Next Stop, Dessert: Street Theater Moves Onto the Subway

body: Perhaps never in the history of bovinity has there been such a mystery as the one surrounding the fiberglass cow painted with colorful street scenes that stared out across the Korean War Veterans Plaza in Downtown Brooklyn. Last summer the creature was in good company. Along with several others like him, he grazed in the grassy quads of Cadman
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; The Last Fiberglass Roundup: Prodigal Cow Comes Home

body: To anyone tempted to call Brooklyn an outer borough, hear this: ''In some ways, I think we're better than the Met.'' This is the word from Jay Meetze, the 27-year-old conductor who is the artistic director of the brand new Opera Company of Brooklyn. Sure the Metropolitan Opera is good, Mr. Meetze acknowledges, but he insists that his offerings are
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Move Over, Zeffirelli: A New Opera Company Thinks Small

body: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. Opera ''LA BOHEME.'' Amato Opera. This company, in its 53rd season, stages its productions on modest but generally attractive sets, and uses reduced orchestrations and singers who can often be
title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: A group of developers is advancing plans for a mixed-income rental building on a site in the far eastern corner of TriBeCa that long has been dotted with vacant lots and mostly empty low-lying structures. The $118.5 million project will contain 330 apartments. Of these, 204 units will be one-bedrooms, and the rest will be studios and two-bedroom
title: Residential Real Estate; A TriBeCa Building Is a Curtain Raiser for a Trio of Developers

body: In Hearing Room 387 at Queens Family Court, lawyers who jam into the closet-sized chamber have had to settle for a not-so-judicial-sounding seat assignment: the windowsill. At Brooklyn Family Court, defendants awaiting their turn overflow into equally grand accommodations: the stairwell. And at Manhattan's 111 Centre Street courthouse, where
title: Halls of Justice Going Up All Over; New York City Nears a Peak In Its Courthouse Building Boom

author: Diane Cole is the author of the memoir ''After Great Pain: A New Life Emerges.''
body: Bless the family symmetry that gave my son, Edward, a first cousin who shares not only his age (almost 12) but also similar passions for general science and general mischief. Unfortunately, they live three hours apart, which limits all but their online time together. So whenever Cousin Steven comes to town, we show him the town: our town. And who
title: Travels With an Aunt: New York for Children

body: Community Capital Bank, a 10-year-old bank based in Downtown Brooklyn that specializes in providing small business loans and individual banking services in lower-income neighborhoods, is opening a branch in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, on Dec. 15. The branch, the bank's second, will occupy a building at 140 58th Street (at First Avenue) that housed a
title: URBAN TACTICS; Brooklyn-Based Bank Coming to Sunset Park

body: A 25-year-old film student died early yesterday in a fire ignited by candles burning near her bed in her downtown Brooklyn apartment, officials said. The woman, Helen Carnegie, was a first-year graduate film student at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. She was the 13th person in New York City this year to die in a fire started by a
title: Student Killed in Fire Started by Candles

body: With a Little Bit of Luck NORMAN LAMM, who is celebrating his 25th year as president of Yeshiva University, would credit exactly one thing for his extended tenure: mazel. ''Just plain good luck,'' he said, translating the Yiddish word. Given that university presidents rarely remain in their posts for as long as a decade, much less a
title: BULLETIN BOARD

body: A few months from now, a new bright blue steel structure that frames the entrance to Downtown Brooklyn may be torn down. Or it may be joined by two others at nearby intersections. It all depends on the outcome of a battle between the organization that erected the arch and the local community board, which says neither it nor the city's Art
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Critics Say an Arch, From a Painter's Blue Period, Isn't Art

body: AMID the resolutely practical small businesses in western Harlem -- the lace curtain stores, the Koreans selling cheap socks and scooters, the hardware suppliers -- the Sweet Chef Southern Styles Bakery is a bright spot, a fanciful sign of a neighborhood on the way up. The shop's glass display cases are sparkling clean. Its pies and cakes -- sweet
title: COPING; Making Harlem Sweeter, One Pie at a Time

author: E-mail: daschn@nytimes.com
body: The Nisei Knick Q.: I've heard that the New York Knicks once had a Japanese point guard. When did he play? A.: Back in the era of the two-handed set shot, Wataru Misaka, a Japanese-American standout at the University of Utah, played in three games for the Knicks in 1947. After playing on Utah's championship teams in 1944 and 1947, he became the
title: F.Y.I.

body: Officer Necktie, as he asked to be called, works the traffic beat in downtown Brooklyn. He has been on the job for more than a year, and by now, he says, he knows it pretty well. For example, he knew that yesterday was supposed to be the day that police officers across New York showed zero tolerance toward traffic violators of all stripes -- double
title: Practically Zero Tolerance on Traffic

body: William S. Woodside, a prominent business and civic leader who used his positions as a platform to promote social change in the New York area and nationwide, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 and also had homes in Scottsdale, Ariz., and Litchfield, Conn. The cause was lung disease, said his wife, Migs. The resume of Mr.
title: William Woodside, Executive, Dies at 78

body: At first blush, it looked like a typical fender bender: a 1989 Mercury sedan with four people inside ran into the car of a woman driving alone in downtown Brooklyn. But even though a police officer noted in his accident report that there were no injuries, three passengers in the Mercury were taken to a medical clinic, where they were treated for
title: Car Crashes Were Staged For Fraud, U.S. Charges

body: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: TAX CUT APPROVED -- The New York City Council voted 39 to 3 yesterday to approve a reduction in the city's personal income tax that would save taxpayers an average of $52 a year. The cut is much smaller than the one proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani nearly a year ago. It was scaled back by the mayor and the Council because
title: METRO BRIEFING

body: After a quarter of a century in which community opposition, lack of government financing and other obstacles thwarted the development of three prime patches at the edge of downtown Brooklyn, New York State moved yesterday to spur housing and retail projects on the sites. State officials invited proposals from developers to buy and build on one of
title: State Seeks Plans for Neglected Brooklyn Area

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Costumes, set pieces, film equipment and other items relating to film, television and video are on permanent display. ''Visions of New York: Films From the 1960's Underground,'' including guest appearances by filmmakers; through
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Coney Island is an eclectic oasis on the edge of an eclectic city. It is home to the Polar Bears, those hearty souls who swim in the Atlantic in February, and the Russian women who stroll the boardwalk in mink coats in July. And, of course, the Cyclone, the rickety-looking roller coaster that roars over an amusement park with a fabled past and a
title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Hit Me With Your Best Shot

body: And this was supposed to be a new and improved New York election. There was the city's nifty new automated phone bank with 38 operators ready to enlighten bewildered voters. There was the revamped training program for the 26,000 brave souls recruited to staff the city's polls. There were the extended Board of Elections office hours, the scan-able
title: THE 2000 ELECTIONS: THE MECHANICS; Preparations for Smooth Day at Polls Run Afoul of Murphy's Law

body: It was a place of the discarded and the dead. There were no roads. There was said to be nothing green that could live. The smell could sicken at a distance of two miles. In the early years of the 20th century, the tiny island off the coast of Brooklyn was a nightmare: a dumping ground for most of the trash and animal carcasses of the teeming city.
title: All the Dead Horses, Next Door; Bittersweet Memories of the City's Island of Garbage

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,'' photographs by Charles Martin, through Dec. 31. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2;
title: SPARE TIMES

body: An investigation by the New York City Council has found that retailers continued to charge the 8.25 percent state sales tax on baby goods, hats, gloves and other merchandise even though the items were exempted from the tax on March 1. City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, who released the findings yesterday at a City Hall news conference, said
title: Council Finds Old Sales Tax Is Still Assessed

body: The Yankee Stadium stop on the No. 4 line smelled not so much like victory yesterday as it did like bleach. Nuris Rosario, a transit worker, was putting her shoulder into her broom, scouring the last residue of the 2000 Subway Series off the long concrete platform. Somehow, though, you could tell that she did not want to wash it all away. It might
title: BASEBALL: SUBWAY SERIES -- TUNNEL VISIONS; A Ride To Work, A Replay Of Victory

body: At 9 p.m. on a recent Monday, cars were double-parked along Rogers Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. No action disturbed the street; the nearest bodega was quiet, and no one loitered on the corner at Martense Street. But behind the doors of the storefront Resurrection Temple of the Lord, a mighty noise ignited, lighted by the spirit of
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; A Twofold Mission Of Piety and Pop

body: Compact video cameras emerged from tote bags, and silver cameras were whisked from the folds of dark suits as the visitors from Hubei Province in China took turns sidling up to an oversized statue and posing with shy half-smiles. They were not standing beside the Statue of Liberty or a hand-painted cow, but admiring a bronze statue depicting a
title: A Police Dept.'s Growing Allure; Crime Fighters From Around World Visit for Tips

body: Four months ago, at the height of the summer tourist season, Greyhound Lines resumed direct bus service to and from Downtown Brooklyn for the first time in 10 years. But community board members say that the service has created traffic snarls and pollution in an already congested part of town, and that they were not consulted about the location for
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Greyhound Skirted Proper Procedure, Local Leaders Charge

body: WE were getting a lot of mail from readers complaining that I never write about New York buildings, so my employers decided to build one. Not just any building, but a work of architecture, a project with the potential to raise the quality of building in New York. Last week, when I learned that Renzo Piano had been chosen to design the new
title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; A Rare Opportunity For Real Architecture Where It's Needed

body: Theater ''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN

body: City officials have decided to settle a federal civil rights case filed by a 19-year-old Brooklyn student who was arrested two years ago for jumping a turnstile when he had, in fact, paid his fare using a MetroCard. The case was one of thousands of fare-beating arrests that have been pursued by the police over the last six years as they have
title: Proof From MetroCard Ends Fare-Beating Case

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has recently opened, with the same hours as the museum. Opening tomorrow, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' live, multicolored
title: SPARE TIMES

body: For seven years, the Public Art Fund has been responsible for the changing landscape of the commons that surround the Metro Tech Center, the complex of corporate offices in downtown Brooklyn that includes Chase Manhattan Bank; Bear, Stearns; and Brooklyn Union Gas. The commons' newest scene is ''Halcyon Days,'' a yearlong exhibition by five New
title: INSIDE ART; A Landscape That Grows Art

body: Oysters, Irish Style An oyster festival sponsored by Guinness, the traditional quaff for oysters in Ireland, will include a Galway-style shucking contest and food for sale and will take place on Saturday from noon to 9 p.m. at East Fourth and Lafayette Streets. The event will benefit the Merchant's House Museum, 29 East Fourth Street. A Day for
title: CALENDAR

body: To the Editor: Your Sept. 28 news article about the encouraging cultural progress in downtown Brooklyn understates the potential of the arts there by not mentioning the roles that nearby campuses play as providers of audiences, performers and artists. Long Island University, along with other nearby educational institutions, is a member of the
title: Artistry in Brooklyn

body: In a typical fairy tale, a frog is an enchanted creature just waiting for his true self to be revealed. In ''Boonah, Come Down,'' the frog is also on a quest, but his transformation is achieved through meditation, -- no princess's kiss required. If this doesn't sound like the Brothers Grimm, well, it's probably because they never explored Eastern
title: FAMILY FARE; Of Frogs And Philosophy

body: I'M kind of a renegade,'' the Brooklyn-born Brian Merlis says about his obsession -- an obsession with collecting that in the last 20 years has cost him $250,000 -- and his marriage. Mr. Merlis doesn't gamble, scuba dive or fly fighter planes. He is an amateur historian and a collector of photographs and artifacts who has apparently published more
title: Streetscapes/Brian Merlis; An Amateur Historian With a Passion for Brooklyn

body: OFFICE vacancies are approaching record lows and rental rates reaching record highs in Manhattan. Despite the demand, there is no speculative construction in the city, with the few buildings that are being constructed substantially preleased before a shovel went into the ground. Across the Hudson River along the New Jersey waterfront, buildings are
title: Commercial Property; An Up Cycle Just Keeps Rolling

body: MOTT HAVEN Capturing a Killer: Artists' Visions of Asthma New York City children are almost three times as likely to be hospitalized for asthma as are children nationwide, and the city's highest rate has been in the Bronx. Local artists have responded with various visual methods of thinking about the problem. The Io-Art Gallery and Adverse
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Lost in the noisy ebullience over New York City's thriving economy is a problem that some economists and elected leaders say could undermine the city's prosperity and cost thousands of jobs at everything from Internet companies to garment manufacturers. The problem is a severe lack of office space in Manhattan and the surrounding boroughs.
title: THE CROWDED CITY; OFFICE SHORTAGE IMPERILS GROWTH IN NEW YORK CITY

body: The city has taken more than six years to renovate a building it owns in Downtown Brooklyn, and Howard Golden, the borough president, who called the lengthy project ''a particular embarrassment,'' wants the work finished fast. But city officials say they need nine more months. At issue is exterior work being done on the building, 345 Adams Street,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; City Gets a Scolding Over a Long-Stalled Renovation

author: Eyal Press is a writer based in New York. This is his first article for the magazine.
body: Name: Mubenga Kanyinda Age: 28 Coming from: Congo Looking for: Freedom I had to leave my country,'' whispered Mubenga Kanyinda in a voice so soft I could barely hear him. It was a Thursday morning in early February, and Kan- yinda was sitting across from me inside a narrow room with pale blue walls and harsh fluorescent lighting. He was shy and
title: No Refuge

body: Borrowing a page from the corporate handbook, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has appointed four community school district superintendents as senior superintendents to mentor and advise their colleagues, who, with the senior superintendents, run the city's 32 school districts. A fifth superintendent is being brought out of retirement to oversee
title: 5 Superintendents to Oversee Colleagues

body: It Was No Busy Signal Schools Chancellor HAROLD O. LEVY was irked recently when he tried to reach several Board of Education administrators by telephone and got their voice mail instead. So he hired a firm, KPMG Consulting, to learn just how many officials at the board's headquarters at 110 Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn do not answer their
title: BULLETIN BOARD

body: September EVENING STARS 2000 DANCE SERIES You couldn't get much smarter and more adventurous than the Evening Stars 2000 Series, which provides a remarkable overview of American dance in six performances. And it's free. The dance component of the festival opens tonight with a shared program by the companies of Ronald K. Brown and Rennie Harris. The
title: THE ANNOTATED LIST; In the Whirl: Uptown, Downtown, All Around Town

body: A federal lawsuit filed yesterday charges that the city's Administration for Children's Services violated the civil rights of a 5-year-old boy and his mother by holding the child in foster care illegally for two and a half years and denying his mother the chance to plead in court for his return. Though the suit, brought by the national advocacy
title: Suit Charges That Boy Was Illegally Kept in Foster Care as Mother Sought Return

body: Immediately, Liz Shipman, the director, gets the emotional center of ''A Midsommer Nights Dreame'' right. In this production by the Kings County Shakespeare Company, no matter what happens in the Athenian court or in the more imposing fairy court of Oberon and Titania, no matter how much amusing confusion Puck produces with his botched
title: THEATER REVIEW; Where Fairies Are as Foolish as the Mortals

body: New York City officials are finding that the road to building a new trading complex for the New York Stock Exchange can be long and bumpy. In response to solicitations by the Giuliani administration, only two developers told the city last Friday that they were interested in building the proposed $727 million, 1.9-million-square-foot trading complex
title: Only 2 Developers Express Interest in Building Trading Complex for Stock Exchange

body: The Daily News will begin distributing a free evening newspaper aimed at commuters starting Sept. 12, executives said yesterday. The new paper, to be called The Daily News Express, will have a staff of about 12 reporters and will generally feature 20 pages of news and 20 pages of advertisements. Street hawkers will hand out the paper at 75
title: Metro Business; Daily News to Start Free Evening Paper

body: In the cramped law library on the top floor of Kings County Family Court, the day begins with frilly dresses, wide grins and cheers of congratulations. A 3-year-old twig of a boy, an orphan since birth, gets parents of his own. A pair of brothers -- one 20 and disabled, the other, 10, with eyes like darts -- are adopted by the quiet couple who took
title: Brooklyn Journal; In Court, Families Sit Waiting On the Law

body: The flags hanging from the windows of homes lining the only cobblestone blocks in Brooklyn Heights all bear the same Revolutionary War motto, ''Don't Tread on Me.'' The flag-waving residents want to stop a park they fear will bring thousands of people walking along their streets every weekend. On the waterfront below Brooklyn Heights, a
title: As Some Fight A Park Plan, Its Supporters See Elitism; Many in Brooklyn Hts. Fear Hordes of Visitors

body: AS their lease drew to a close at 160-170 Varick Street on the lower west side of Manhattan, executives of Colahan Saunders Corporation, a commercial printing company, knew they were going to have to move. Their landlord, Trinity Church Real Estate, was converting its portfolio of buildings from largely industrial uses to offices, at rents
title: Commercial Property/Long Island City, Queens; Crossing the Queensboro Bridge as a Resettler

body: OFFICE rents, which have been rising steadily for several years, spiked upward in the second quarter of this year, leading some real estate executives to express concern that vital service providers, such as smaller law and accounting firms, may be driven out of Manhattan. According to figures compiled by the Williams Real Estate company, the
title: Commercial Property/The Manhattan Market; Office Rents Are Up Sharply in the Second Quarter

body: Two underground electrical fires in downtown Brooklyn sent thick, black smoke billowing out of manholes and subway entrances and forced the closing of four of the city's busiest subway lines yesterday just as the evening commute was beginning, stranding tens of thousands of riders in Manhattan and Brooklyn. As subway fires go, the ones that began
title: 2 Fires Disrupt Subway Lines In Manhattan And Brooklyn

body: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Foreign Minister Quits As Israeli Turmoil Grows Foreign Minister David Levy resigned over Prime Minister Ehud Barak's willingness to compromise with the Palestinians on Jerusalem. And four bills calling for new elections passed in the Knesset. A17 Donations Uproar in Japan The government of Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori was
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: IF you have set foot on a subway platform during the last 20 years, there is a decent chance he has been standing there next to you, a small, smiling man in no hurry to catch a train. He was probably carrying a green satchel with a tiny American flag stitched on the flap. From this satchel, he probably produced a pair of junk store binoculars or a
title: Smitten by the Subway

body: Three people were missing and feared dead last night after an explosion destroyed a three-story red-brick building near downtown Brooklyn and heavily damaged the house next door, the authorities said. The 7:45 p.m. explosion, which reduced 420 State Street in Boerum Hill to a pile of beams and bricks and damaged its neighbor, 418 State Street,
title: Blast Levels a Brooklyn Building; 3 People Are Missing

body: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Mideast Summit Meeting Opens at Camp David Israeli and Palestinian leaders began their peace summit at Camp David. President Clinton ushered the leaders into the presidential retreat where he hopes for a ''principled compromise.'' A1 Nigerians Killed by Blast More than 100 people were killed after a damaged gasoline pipeline
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: Developers pitching projects as varied as the expansion of an Astoria film studio to the construction of a large shopping center in East Harlem ranked among the biggest spenders last year on New York City lobbyists, according to a report released yesterday. Since the start of the Giuliani administration in 1994, spending on the lobbyists who try to
title: Lobbyists Putting Muscle Behind Real Estate

body: Theater ''VENUS AND ADONIS,'' Shakespeare's 1593 bawdy epic poem about the love goddess and her unsuccessful seduction of young Adonis, has been adapted into a comedy by the Shakespeare Project, performed by live actors and puppets. Today through Sunday at 6 p.m. at Rector Park in Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan, as part of the Hudson River
title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN

body: The inspector general for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is investigating allegations that supervisors who oversee the subway's signal system failed to make hundreds of inspections of the lights that direct trains throughout the city. Officials with New York City Transit said yesterday that they had learned of the allegations late last
title: Subway Signal Inspections Under Review

body: The B train that derailed Tuesday night in downtown Brooklyn, injuring 95 passengers, was traveling along a route it did not usually take and was crossing back to its own tracks when its third car jumped off the rails, transit officials said yesterday. Officials said it could be several weeks before they determined what caused the accident, which
title: Officials Focus on Subway Switch as Cause of Derailment

body: The transit workers arrived by the dozens, piling out of trucks and wearing orange vests and helmets, like soldiers ready for battle. Some had trained for exactly such a moment. Others could not have known what to expect when they stepped into the subway tunnel beneath the DeKalb Avenue station in downtown Brooklyn. Billowing smoke. People
title: 2 Derailed Cars, 70 Feet of Damaged Track, 8 Frantic Hours

body: Eighty-four people were hurt, three of them critically, when a subway train derailed as it pulled out of a station in downtown Brooklyn last night, hurling passengers into one another and against the train's windows, causing many head injuries, the authorities said. As the southbound B train left the DeKalb Avenue station at 9:57 p.m., the third
title: Train Derails In Brooklyn, Injuring Scores

body: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Taiwan Leader Extends Invitation to Beijing Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, left, emboldened by the warm summit meeting between the leaders of North and South Korea, invited his Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, to join him in a similar effort. title: NEWS SUMMARY

author: Phillip Lopate, a novelist and essayist, is the editor of ''Writing New York'' (Library of America, 1998), a collection of writings about the city.
body: IN Borges's story ''The Aleph,'' the narrator opens the trapdoor of a cellar to find himself staring at ''millions of acts both delightful and awful,'' all of which simultaneously ''occupied the same point in space.'' So a newcomer might feel, arriving in New York City for the first time. How does one begin to ''read'' New York, to make sense of
title: New York, Brick by Brick

body: To help budding entrepreneurs answer questions about starting their own businesses -- ''How much money should I have in the bank during the first year?'' and ''When should I break from my career to begin?'' -- the Brooklyn Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit agency that helps create jobs in the borough, this month opened a center for
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Assistance in Brooklyn For Would-Be Entrepreneurs

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council leaders joked this week about what to call them: the ''outer boroughs'' or the ''other boroughs''? But the reason for the bantering was no joke: the $37.6 billion budget approved this week includes an unusually large share of money and other perks for sections of the city outside Manhattan. The 2001 budget
title: Budget Offers Perks to Boroughs Other Than Manhattan

title: Trial to Open for Former Executive of U.S. Agency in a Murder-for-Hire Case

body: A water-main break in downtown Brooklyn flooded several businesses yesterday and closed a busy block of Atlantic Avenue for several hours, fire officials said. Construction has been under way on water and gas pipes this week, and Deputy Fire Chief Robert Hovsepian said that a 30-inch water main ruptured during the afternoon. The basements of at
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Broken Main Floods Several Brooklyn Shops

body: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN Gardener's Gambit: Peony to King Four An outdoor living chess garden is the big (1,000 square feet) attraction in the third annual Metrotech Garden Festival, which opens at noon tomorrow. The garden is made up of chess pieces that are rolling planters of formal topiary, flowers and shrubs. International champions and local chess
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. * ABDELLI, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400 or (212) 545-7536. Abderrahmane Abdelli is a Berber from the Kabylia region of Algeria,
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

body: A 60-year-old woman died after being run over by a private bus in Downtown Brooklyn yesterday, the police said. The woman, Digna Fontanez, was trying to cross Livingston Street, a busy four-lane street, just west of its intersection with Flatbush Avenue at 3:10 p.m., and she made it only halfway across, witnesses told the police. Witnesses said she
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Woman Crossing Street Is Killed by a Bus

body: IS architecture an art? What restrictions can government place on architects without violating constitutional principles? A new proposal to overhaul the city's zoning laws is now forcing New Yorkers to confront these fundamental questions. Titled the Uniform Bulk Program, the proposal amounts to the architectural manifesto of the Giuliani
title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; Reaching For Power Over Streets And Sky

body: He has been the man so in control that he could almost be heard setting his jaw. He has been the man who knows what is best for everybody, the man who takes it upon himself to restore morality to Gomorrah on the Hudson. For better, for worse, for seven years, he has been the man. Then, over a span of a few days that culminated with an extraordinary
title: A New Side of a Familiar Man

body: Over sandwiches and keyboards yesterday, at soda machines and bus stops, it seemed as if New Yorkers were hardly surprised by the news: the marital problems of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his wife, Donna Hanover. ''Come on, we knew a long time ago this wasn't much of a marriage,'' said Sidney Levitan, 89, a retired high school administrator.
title: THE MAYOR'S SEPARATION: THE REACTION; Giuliani's Marital Uproar Brings Winces and Sighs

body: To the Editor: Re ''Turning a Kiosk Into a Borough Gateway'' (April 2): The north face of the kiosk, nearest Flatbush Avenue, was -- until it was removed a couple of years ago -- the location of my all-time favorite traffic sign: ''No standing at all times.'' I miss its grammatical incoherence and would dearly love to secure one to display. ELLIOTT
title: Life Under the Billboard Blanket; Brooklyn Kiosk Carried Sign That Turned Heads

body: FOR CHILDREN Theater ''PLAYS 2000: NEW WORKS FROM URBAN YOUTH THEATER.'' Henry Street Settlement's Urban Youth Theater will present five one-acts, written and performed by students of the program and directed by faculty members and guest artists, at Henry Street Settlement's Experimental Theater, Abrons Arts Center, 466 Grand Street, Lower East
title: SPARE TIMES

body: The protesters who headed to the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday morning, led by the Rev. Herbert Daughtry in a march against police brutality, were making a point with their attire as well as their agenda. In support of an economic boycott, the nearly 200 protesters spurned Easter finery and spring hats for denim and baseball caps, and planned to march
title: Officers Halt Protest March Against Police

body: Dismayed over two towering buildings currently rising in Brooklyn Heights, community groups packed Borough Hall on Monday to demand that the city impose stricter limits in its proposed rezoning of downtown Brooklyn. In a proposal presented by the Department of City Planning to Borough President Howard Golden, the city would create a Special
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKYLN UP CLOSE; Residents Seek a Tighter Cap On Towers in Their Midst

body: The potential for development in Brooklyn -- including concepts for a freight tunnel to Staten Island and a new cultural district downtown -- is the focus of a three-morning conference starting tomorrow sponsored by the Steven L. Newman Real Estate Institute at Baruch College. The second session is scheduled for May 8 and the third for May 22. All
title: POSTINGS: Conference at Baruch College; The Future Of Brooklyn

body: The Cyclone, the famed wooden roller coaster at Coney Island, starts up another white-knuckle season. With other reports from the West Village, Upper West Side, Upper East Side, Midtown, Greenwich Village, SoHo, Broad Channel, Downtown Brooklyn, South Brooklyn, Hunts Point and Pelham Parkway. PAGES 5-9 NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT; Let the Screams Begin

body: Peter Bloom knew he had made the right school choice five years ago when he visited his son's kindergarten class and reached for a batch of muffins the students had just baked. His son gave him a reproachful look. ''Dad,'' he said, ''those are for the homeless shelter.'' Brooklyn Friends School has long been known as the warm and fuzzy New York
title: Private School Reassesses in Wake of a Departure

body: A cloud of pink dust from a pack of dye used to catch bank robbers forced the shutdown of a subway station in Downtown Brooklyn for more than an hour last night, the authorities said. After the dust settled, how the pack got into the Jay Street-Borough Hall station remained a mystery. No bank robberies were reported nearby -- banks were closed
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Subway Station Is Closed After Dye Pack Explodes

body: This is a sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations). This selection, compiled by the critic Paul Griffiths, represents what caught his eye and excited his expectations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured
title: A Chorus of Alleluias and Glorias Herald Easter Season

body: An off-duty police officer moonlighting as a security guard in a downtown Brooklyn clothing store killed a 17-year-old boy last evening in a gunfight that began after the youth and a friend set off the store's theft alarm, the police said. The friend and a store clerk were each shot in the leg during the gunfight, which filled the store's entryway
title: Off-Duty Officer Kills Youth in Brooklyn Store

body: IN America, more than 200,000 guns are traced by law enforcement each year. This is the story of one of those weapons -- named after its serial number -- No. 997126, a 12-shot, 9 millimeter Jennings semi-automatic. The gun, made mostly of plastic, was manufactured in 1995, at a factory near John Wayne International Airport in Costa Mesa, Calif. It
title: THE NATION; The Biography of a Gun

body: Snaking under the streets of Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn are 175 miles of thick cast-iron pipes that were laid nearly a century ago to help a developing city deal with the ever-present danger of fire. In its day, the high-pressure water system was considered the ultimate in firefighting technology, but like most innovations, it eventually
title: City Finds a Fiber-Optic Solution Underfoot, in Old Pipes

body: FROM the time the first discussions began until it opened its doors in July 1998, Renaissance Plaza in downtown Brooklyn was a 15-year undertaking, with much of the uncertainty that delayed the project centered on the 376-room hotel that is part of the 1.4-million-square-foot building, which also contains offices and stores. But less than two years
title: Commercial Property/Downtown Brooklyn; Open Only Two Years, a Hotel Is Ready to Expand

body: Saying Brooklyn deserves a visual gateway to welcome visitors, community groups have long pushed for restoration of a graffiti-covered kiosk that once housed a subway entrance and newsstand. But now that the city plans to renovate the 92-year-old kiosk, on a traffic island bounded by Flatbush, Atlantic and Fourth Avenues, there is disagreement on
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Turning a Kiosk Into a Borough Gateway

body: HAD Stephon Marbury remained at Georgia Tech for four long years and helped keep the departing Bobby Cremins's program afloat, he would be a rookie now in the National Basketball Association, greener all over except in the wallet. The Nets' best player was at his dressing stall one night last week when he was asked if at any time as a millionaire
title: Sports of The Times; In an Often Shady and Dirty Business, It Is Business as Usual

body: Theater ''APPELEMANDO'S DREAMS.'' The title character in Patricia Polacco's picture book can see things that adults can't or won't see. He also perceives light and color where adults see only drabness. The tale has been adapted into a light opera by the librettist Barbara Zinn Krieger and the composer James Kurtz. They've embellished the book's
title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: Thousands of young adults in New York City's foster care system, many of them neglected or abandoned during the height of the city's crack epidemic a decade ago, have been moved out of the system in recent years, forced to fend for themselves at 18 and often with little education or financial resources. The city's child welfare system, whose legal
title: Youths Leaving Foster Care System With Few Skills or Resources

body: HERBERT STURZ is not a name readily recognizable to 98 percent of New Yorkers. This pleases Mr. Sturz. But inquire of the remaining 2 percent -- public- and private-sector types alike, who have left their own crater-size footprints in criminal justice, real estate development and social welfare policies in the city -- and the booming response is
title: PUBLIC LIVES; A Man Who Gives Credit Where It's Due

body: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS and neighboring Cobble Hill have long been the home to locally owned businesses catering to the residents of the largely low-rise neighborhoods and the nearby court system. But now the area is beginning to attract national retailers, at the same time as some local businesses are expanding. CVS Pharmacy has leased 12,000 square feet
title: Commercial Property/Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill; National Chains Vie for Piece of the Local Retail Pie

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. The parlor is filled with period furniture. ''Moments in Staten's Island's Black Heritage,'' photographs from 1880 to the turn
title: SPARE TIMES

body: It's not a job with a future, but the future of many neighborhoods in America may be affected by how well the job is done. Every 10 years, the Census Bureau hires an army of census takers -- enumerators, in bureau parlance. For the 2000 count, which has just begun, the bureau needs about a half-million of them. The job lasts only six weeks or so.
title: Census Takers Moved by Money And Civic Duty; A Temp Position That Counts, Even if It Doesn't Last Long

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city was aggressively seeking a buyer for 110 Livingston Street, the Board of Education's decrepit and maligned headquarters in downtown Brooklyn, and that he was not going to wait for the board's study exploring the possibility of a sale. ''Study!'' Mr. Giuliani said derisively at a news
title: Mayor Says School Board's Base Is for Sale, Study or No

body: John P. Keith, a former president of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit planning agency for the New York City metropolitan area, died Thursday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 78. The cause of death was congestive heart failure, said his wife, Doris. Mr. Keith was president of the association from 1969 to 1989. Previously, he spent 10
title: John P. Keith, 78, President Of Regional Plan Association

Ratner, is once more trying his hand at creating environments that focus on contemporary art. This time Mr. Ratner is installing art in two new Manhattan hotels opening this spring. ''I
title: INSIDE ART

body: The halls of the Brooklyn Tabernacle shook with the exhortations of the Rev. Jim Cymbala yesterday, and Carol Cymbala, leading the choir, worked the piano as she has done for 27 years, as if nothing at all were different about this day. But there was. The 270-voice Brooklyn Tabernacle Choir was singing for the first time in public since winning its
title: Brooklyn Choir Wins Praise by Singing the Lord's Praises

body: A decade after Greyhound stopped direct long-distance service to and from Brooklyn, two local businessmen are trying to return the bus company to the borough. But some community board members have raised concerns about noise and pollution from buses. Darnell Canada, president of the Fort Greene Empowerment Organization, a community group, and
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE; Long-Absent Greyhounds May Return To Brooklyn

body: JERRY NOONAN has what he calls ''a nice problem.'' Nearly all 400 boxes at his Mail Boxes Etc. outlet on the Avenue of the Americas near 14th Street have been rented, so Mr. Noonan, who owns the franchise, has come up with what he calls the ''virtual mailbox.'' Instead of getting keys to an actual box, customers go to the desk and ask for their
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Little Boxes, Little Boxes

body: Grasping a bar designed to help blind children keep their balance as they play, 4-year-old Monique jumps up and down on a small yellow trampoline. Suddenly, Joshua, a tall, husky boy, jumps on behind her. Ignoring the bar, he bounces hard, throwing her off balance. ''Stand up, Monique!'' cries one of her teachers. Monique frowns. ''He keeps
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; Blind Children Take a Small Step Toward Public School

body: At the 84th Precinct in downtown Brooklyn, the officers on duty started gathering in the lounge when word came that the verdict would soon be announced. It would be ridiculous to say that the half-dozen patrolmen who gathered were anxious or concerned or rapt. It was more than that: a tidal wave could have engulfed the neighborhood and still they
title: THE DIALLO VERDICT: THE POLICE; At a Brooklyn Precinct, Tension, Then Jubilation

body: THE big guy, Jimmy Fyfe, all hulking 6 feet 7 inches Norwegian-Scottish-Irish of him, with the coarse street talk of a Brooklyn cop, abruptly gets tearful. In June 1998, he recounts, his son-in-law, a black graduate student at the University of Illinois who was a political refugee from the Ivory Coast, was stomped to death by a white bouncer
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Police Reformer Draws on His Experience

body: It opened at the height of the Roaring Twenties as the headquarters for the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, a luxurious private club with a ballroom, more than 200 dormitory rooms, a library, bowling alleys, handball courts, Turkish baths and a swimming pool. But after becoming a casualty of the Depression, mismanagement and failure, it
title: School Bureaucracy Set in Stone, and Mortar; But Inside Building, Humanity Shows

author: John Waldman is the author of ''Heartbeats in the Muck: The History, Sea Life and Environment of New York Harbor,'' published last month by Lyons Press.
body: THERE are standard, packaged ways to meet New York Harbor -- taking the Circle Line tour or the Staten Island Ferry -- and in doing so one can see many of its renowned sights. But to learn the essential character of the harbor, one must see its many uncelebrated spaces, large and small. The New Yorker writer Joseph Mitchell knew this a half century
title: The Harbor Nobody Knows; New York's Reviving Waterfront Teems With Hidden Treasures

body: AT Nina America on West 27th Street, identical female mannequin heads with large vacant eyes and saucy smiles line the office shelves, an army of faces topped with wigs, from flaxen curls to purplish pageboys. Amid stacks of cardboard boxes from China, employees work the phones, brokering human hair. Nina America is one of more than a dozen
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Rapunzel's Offspring Are Cashing In

body: While stands the Coliseum, Rome shall stand; When falls the Coliseum, Rome shall fall. Lord Byron ''Childe Harold's Pilgrimage'' Good thing this is New York. Having stood 1,920 years fewer than the one in Rome, the Coliseum on Columbus Circle is about to topple. Its facade is already being shrouded in the funereal pall of safety netting as workers
title: Built, but Not Destined, to Last; A Robert Moses Legacy, Coliseum Is Coming Down

body: The New York Times Company has taken an important step toward creating a new headquarters in the Times Square area. It has selected a developer to help in its negotiations with state and city officials to build a 1.37 million-square-foot tower across from the Port Authority Bus Terminal, according to the company and government officials. The
title: Times Co. Picks Developer For New Home in Times Sq.

title: SPARE TIMES

body: ACROSS the street from the American Museum of Natural History, Betsy Gotbaum, director of the New-York Historical Society, has been watching the construction of the dazzling, hugely trumpeted $210 million planetarium with great interest and strong emotions. ''Ellen took a place that was moribund and has done something spectacular,'' Ms. Gotbaum
title: What It Takes

body: A Fire Department employee was arrested early yesterday on charges of raping a co-worker inside the computer room where they worked. The woman told the police that she was working with the suspect, Winston Meusa, 42, in the Fire Department's computer tape library at 11 Metrotech Center in downtown Brooklyn at 1:30 a.m. when he knocked her to the
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Fire Department Worker Arrested on Rape Charge

body: To the Editor: As one of the nearly 60,000 daily commuters who use the DeKalb Avenue subway stop in downtown Brooklyn, no matter how it's spelled, I am delighted to see such ambitious plans for this venerable station's restoration (news article, Feb. 3). What interests me and many other old Brooklynites, though, is not whether the station should be
title: Ah, a Subway Station Grows in Brooklyn

body: When Lee Harris Pomeroy was a student at Brooklyn Technical High School in the 1940's, he thought that the DeKalb Avenue subway station in downtown Brooklyn, part of his daily commute to class, was ''old and tired and looked as if it could use work.'' A half-century later, the busy station in the heart of the borough's business center is even older
title: Untangling Knots in the Subway; Architect's Challenge Is to Make DeKalb Station Flow

body: IN what may be the single boldest zoning proposal since 1961, New York City's planning chief, Joseph B. Rose, says he wants to simplify the rules governing the size of new buildings. But even a simplified zoning proposal is not simple. Groups as sophisticated as the Real Estate Board of New York and the Municipal Art Society have had to hire zoning
title: A Complex Plan's Aim: Simpler Zoning Rules

body: All New York City mayors dream about changing the face of their realm, of erecting a physical legacy. Fiorello La Guardia is remembered for his public housing, the airport that bears his name and the alliance he forged with Robert Moses, the most grandiose builder of all. John V. Lindsay fought for urban renewal. Edward I. Koch is credited with the
title: Master Plans or Pipe Dreams; Giuliani Proposes Monuments; Skeptics See Fantasies

body: Hillary Rodham Clinton today sharpened her attacks on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's education agenda, criticizing his support for school vouchers and suggesting that his attacks on the New York City Board of Education were counterproductive. Mrs. Clinton never once mentioned the name of her likely opponent in this year's race for the United States
title: Mrs. Clinton Steps Up Attacks On Giuliani's Schools Agenda

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani brought his escalating campaign against the New York City Board of Education to the Capitol today, calling on state lawmakers to abolish the seven-member board and give the mayor greater control over the city school system. In an hourlong address outlining his legislative priorities, the mayor complained that the central
title: Mayor Urges Lawmakers to Eliminate City School Board

body: The detritus of urban life litters the streets of Boerum Hill: candy wrappers, soda cans and other jetsam, much of it cast off by people walking through on their way to downtown Brooklyn. In other neighborhoods near commercial districts, the Department of Sanitation puts out litter baskets and empties them daily. And shopkeepers can ''adopt'' trash
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; Avid Wastebasket Adopters Get Hard Time From City

body: EVERY day there seems to be a geometric increase in the number of deals being offered through the Internet. Get Rich Quick! Lose Weight Now! Earn Free Dollars! So when Ray Shawn Williams decided on a lark to fill out a form for an online lottery that promised the winner a semester of free student housing, he figured it was just another gimmick. On
title: Habitats/Brooklyn; A Dorm Room Rent-Free, Won in an Online Lottery

body: In using his annual State of the City address to offer a shopping list for economic development, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday ranged across a spectrum of projects, real or only dreamed of, including such diverse public works as improvements to the East River Park and tax incentives for new offices in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens. As it has
title: Now, Mayor Says, Is Time to Build Up, Under and All Around

body: It's not exactly as complicated as the cockpit of a jet. It has two handles: one for the brake and one for the speed. It has a little button for the horn, a digital speedometer and a brake pressure gauge that looks like something from the boiler room of the Mauretania. No automatic pilot. No radar. Not even a seat belt sign (because there are no
title: A Safe Place to Make Mistakes

body: In front of a lush, eye-popping backdrop of the Times Square New Year's Eve celebration, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani delivered a theatrical State of the City address yesterday that was both a reprise of what he considers his greatest triumphs and an effort to impose his legacy on New York City far into the next decade. The speech often sounded like a
title: A Theatrical Giuliani Speaks, But Is It Goodbye or Hello?

body: It sounded like an offhand joke, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani insisted yesterday that he was serious. He wants to sell the New York City Board of Education headquarters at 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn to shrink what he has repeatedly called a bloated bureaucracy and end the Board of Education. A new ''smart'' building could house 75 percent
title: Mayor's Tough Medicine For the Schools System

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; To Take The Census, First Recruit Census Takers

body: The relationship between Rudy Crew and Rudolph W. Giuliani had been ice cold for months when, as Dr. Crew tells it, the mayor surprised the schools chancellor by ushering him into his City Hall inner office after a meeting last September. ''He said, 'Listen, I'm hoping there's some way we can bury the hatchet,' '' Dr. Crew recalled yesterday. ''I
title: Crew Reflects on the Job, and the Rift That Helped to End It

author: Ramon Cortines was New York City schools chancellor from 1993 to 1995.
body: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani says that the next New York schools chancellor should be a good administrator and manager, not necessarily someone with experience as an educator -- ''the kind of person,'' he said, ''that could run a very, very complex business or multinational corporation.'' But the idea that the school system needs a manager is a straw
title: Why Chancellors Fail in New York

body: WITH little commercial activity and only one subway line to Manhattan, Clinton Hill has long been a place that turns in early for the night. Now, though, this low-profile Brooklyn neighborhood is getting attention from people priced out of other parts of the city. Like its sister neighborhood, Fort Greene, with which it is often compared, Clinton
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; Historic, Diverse and on the Rise

body: As she lay in bed dying of cancer, Verna Peebles's sister asked for one last thing: that Ms. Peebles raise her 7-year-old grandson. Ms. Peebles, 58, had already raised four children of her own -- her oldest is 38, her youngest 28 -- but on Dec. 9, 1998, she waited for the car that would bring Steven Branch, her grandnephew, from Norfolk, Va., to
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Helping Orphan Settle Into a New Home
